text: And the first speaker will be Dr. Rachel Thomas. Rachel is the founding director of the Center for Applied Data Ethics at the University of San Francisco and co-founder of Fast AI, where she helped create the most popular free online course on deep learning, bringing people from around the world with diverse and non-traditional backgrounds into AI. She was selected by the Forbes as one of 20 incredible women in AI in 2017 and was profiled in the book Women Tech Founders on the Rise. She earned her PhD in mathematics at Duke University, where she worked on mathematical analysis of biochemical networks. Thank you, Rachel, and welcome. Thank you for having me. All right. Yeah, so I, as mentioned, I'm director of the Center for Applied Data Ethics at USF. And this is because I'm concerned about harms due to misuse of data, including algorithmic bias and issues around fairness. I also really see the potential of machine learning and in that capacity, Fast AI, which is a nonprofit research lab with the goal of making deep learning more accessible to people in a variety of domains. We really want domain experts to be able to use state-of-the-art deep learning. We've had a number of radiologists take our course that are now contributing, cutting edge work. And I think we're at a really, really crucial point in time where there's a lot of promise to be had for machine learning, but also a lot of potential risk and harms. And so we need to be careful about how we approach things. And my goal here is to help widen and enlarge the conversation that we're having on unfairness and bias because we're often just talking about a narrow slice of the issues that are out there. The FDA issued guidelines last year on enhancing the diversity of clinical trial populations. This is an incredibly important topic, and we've definitely seen the harms of what happens if you, for instance, only have white men in your trial. And while this is important, it does not solve all our problems, however. So one example comes from Fitbits, which are currently used in almost 300 clinical trials. And they provide a cheap way to measure heart rate. However, Fitbits and other wearable fitness monitors primarily use a green light technology to track heart rate, which is less accurate on people of color. So the readings are kind of lower quality if you have more melanin in your skin. And so this is an issue where, including people of color in your clinical trial, while important, is not going to address issues when the measurements are systematically biased, or at least kind of biased towards being inaccurate. Another example comes from this paper from Zayed Obermeyer et al that was published in Science last year and covered by Nature. And it looked at a algorithm that was in use in a real health care system impacting millions of people. And it was used to flag patients that were high risk and in need of extra support and extra care. And it was found to be biased against Black patients. And here, the training set had included white and Black patients. And the average health care expenditure of both groups was the same. The underlying issue arose because essentially, the algorithm was using health care expenditure as a proxy for sickness levels. However, on the whole, Black patients were receiving less health care for a given sickness level. And so using spending as a proxy had a very biased result. And fortunately, this is something that was resolved by introducing a new metric. But this is a really common issue in that we were typically using proxies for the things that we really care about. We may not have the measurements for what we most care about. And we have to rely on billing codes or other proxies. And so these two examples of the Fitbits as well as this using a proxy are both examples of measurement bias. And it's important to understand that there are different sources of bias because they require different interventions. So the example we hear about most is representation bias. And this is what happens in, for instance, the study we heard about last month, where the researchers looked at what happens if you train a CNN on chest X-rays from a group that's 100% male or 75% male. They also looked at the reverse, 75% female or 100% female. And they found, not surprisingly, that a classifier trained on a really gender-imbalanced data set of chest X-rays resulted in a model that was less accurate for the other gender. A third type of bias that's really crucial to understand is historical bias. And historical bias is a fundamental structural issue with the first step of the data generation process and can exist even given perfect sampling and feature selection. Historical bias, I think, can also be referred to as systemic racism or systemic sexism. And it's very pervasive across society, across different fields. We hear about it a lot in the criminal justice system and algorithms built within the criminal justice system having very racially biased outputs because all the data is so racially biased. I've studied this in my own industry, in the tech industry, the way that bias shows up in hiring, in performance reviews, in promotions. So medicine is no different. We see a lot of historical bias in medicine. And I'm not trying to pick on doctors or medicine because this is true of so many areas of society. There's a wealth of research on this around gender and racial disparities on who receives pain medication, who receives prompt diagnoses. And I'll just share a few takeaways with you. A meta-analysis of 20 years of published research found that Black patients were 22% less likely than whites to get any pain medication and 29% less likely to be treated with opioids. And this difference even extended to children with Black children receiving less pain medication than white children for the same conditions. Research shows that doctors take the pain of women less seriously than the pain of men. And this shows up in prescribing less pain medication with longer delays and more often ascribing pain to psychogenic causes. And so there have been studies where patients report lower back pain. And the same complaint, if it's coming from a man, is more likely to receive pain medication. Coming from a woman is more likely to receive antidepressants. And so I was invited here, I believe, as a researcher in deep learning and in data ethics and algorithmic bias. However, there's another area where I have expertise, which is as a patient. In the past five years, I've had brain surgery twice, a life-threatening brain infection, and several hospital stays. I'm just going to share one experience with you, which was in 2015 when this all started. I had no history of headaches. And I developed a really, really severe headache. It was the worst pain in my life, it lasted for several days. I didn't go to work. I was trying to stay in a dark room and not look at screens, take over the counter medication. Nothing was helping. And so I went to an ER. And after many hours, they dismissed me. And they said, it's just a headache. They didn't run any tests. They told me to go home and take aspirin. And that was very devastating. And to feel that gap between what I was experiencing and what I could convince a health care worker I was experiencing. Fortunately, I went to a different ER a day or two later where they did an MRI. As soon as they got the results, they transferred me to the neuro ICU. And I had brain surgery the next week. On the whole, I think I've had access to very excellent medical care. I'm very fortunate. Yet at the same time, I've had a number of very, very discouraging experiences of being dismissed or disbelieved. Domain expertise is crucial for any applied machine learning project. And in medicine, this needs to include doctors and patients. And so I think we talk more about the particular domain expertise which doctors have, which is incredibly valuable and important. But patients have a unique and distinctive set of domain expertise as well. And that includes both knowledge about what they are experiencing in their own bodies, as well as how to navigate the medical system from a patient's perspective, which can be quite challenging. And I think this often includes information that is not captured in any electronic health record. So another area where we see bias is diagnosis delays. On average, it takes five years and five doctors for patients with autoimmune diseases, 75% of whom are women, to get a correct diagnosis. Diagnosis of Crohn's disease takes 12 months for men, on average 20 months for women. Diagnosis for Ehlers-Danlos syndrome takes four years for men and 16 years for women. And for many types of cancer, women have to make more visits to their general practitioner before they are referred to a specialist. And so all this shows up in our data. And it's crucial to understand these biases, to understand what's missing from our data, what's incomplete, what's incorrect. And in my story, I think about all the MRIs that aren't taken, the patients that don't persist and don't go to a second ER or third ER or kind of don't have the resources to do so. And all that is going to show up in our data in various ways. And we have to understand those factors. Furthermore, the medical system as a whole can be disempowering and even traumatic for many patients. Aubrey Hirsch wrote a very powerful comic. And I encourage you to look it up in full about her experience. She has Graves' disease. But it took her six years to get a diagnosis. And by the time she did, she suffered permanent damage to her eyes, bones, and heart because of the years that she went undiagnosed. She talks about doctors dismissing her as her list of symptoms must just be due to anxiety. She writes, I knew my body and I knew something was wrong, but I couldn't get anyone to listen to me. So many doctors tell her that she's fine, that she begins to internalize that and to doubt herself, even as she is suffering severe symptoms. She writes, I assume that what happened to me was a fluke, that I had fallen through some crack in the system. But I've since learned that my experience was entirely typical. And so I think those are some perspectives that are important to understand about kind of the medical data itself, about how patients experience the medical system. Something that's important to understand from the machine learning perspective is that we're seeing, and we're seeing this, I would say more so in fields outside of medicine right now, but that machine learning is often having the effect of further concentrating and centralizing power. And this is often unintentional, but it's something that I think we really need to be wary of or conscious of in trying to avoid as we use machine learning more and more in medicine. There's an algorithm that's used in many of the 50 states to determine Medicaid benefits. And when it was implemented in Arkansas, there was a bug in the software code that incorrectly cut benefits for people with cerebral palsy, including Tammy Dobbs, who was interviewed in this Verge article. And so what happened is there was this drastic, kind of drastic cut in care for people with cerebral palsy. They couldn't get any explanation, and there was no system of recourse in place, because there was no system to identify or address mistakes. And fortunately, this eventually surfaced after a lengthy court case, but that's really not the ideal approach. And this is a common issue that we see with many machine learning systems being implemented, but not having a system for recourse. Another issue in this case was that nobody wanted to take responsibility. The creator of the algorithm who is, this is a proprietary black box algorithm that he's earning royalties off of, he said it wasn't his responsibility, and he blamed the policymakers. The policymakers could blame the engineers that implemented this. And I don't say this because it's not that casting blame is important, it's that we need to have a notion of responsibility to ensure better outcomes. And this is not unique to machine learning systems, this is common in all bureaucracies, but as Dana Boyd has observed, algorithmic systems are often extending bureaucracy right now. And so some of the ways that ML can have the effect of centralizing power, of course, it does not always, is that it can be used at massive scale, very cheaply. It can replicate identical biases or errors at scale. While humans are certainly very biased, as I showed earlier, at least there's variation across the population. ML can be used to evade responsibility, can be implemented with no system for recourse. It can create feedback loops, and a feedback loop occurs whenever you're no longer just observing the data, but when the output from your model influences what the next round of data looks like, and it can amplify, not just encode bias. And so it's good to be conscious of these risks. Fortunately, there's been some really, really positive work happening in the machine learning community towards moving our conversation beyond just fairness, which is important, but expanding it to talk about power and participation as well. Dr. Simit Gabru, who got her PhD here at Stanford, is one of the foremost experts on this topic, and she wrote in the New York Times, a lot of times people are talking about bias in the sense of equalizing performance across groups. Oops. They're not thinking about the underlying foundation, whether a task should exist in the first place, who creates it, who will deploy it on which population, who owns the data, and how is it used? And these are really, really crucial questions to be asking. Rhea Kaluri wrote a great article in Nature last month, encouraging us to move from asking, is this AI fair, to asking, how does this AI shift power? And just a few weeks ago, one of the major academic machine learning conferences, ICML, was held, and there was a fantastic workshop on participatory approaches to machine learning. And there, they talked about moving beyond kind of narrow definitions of predictive accuracy to trying to think more about holistic good decision-making in complex real-world cases. Moving beyond transparency to contestability, because what good is transparency if you can't critique or contest the decisions that an algorithm is making. And moving from explainability to recourse. Again, how can those who are impacted by a system, what sort of actions can they take to get kind of changes to the outputs? And so I was very excited to see this work. I encourage you to check it out. I think it's available online, the papers and talks. You need to listen to patients to understand the ways that their data is incomplete and correct, and biased, and I don't think this is something that you can understand apart from talking to patients. You also need to listen to patients to understand the ways the medical system is disempowering. And so we can hopefully avoid having machine learning contribute to that. So I want to challenge all of you to think about what would it look like to include patients in all stages of your process, and to do this in meaningful ways that are not just participation washing. And I'm going to close with a quote from AI researcher Deborah Rajee. She wrote, data are not bricks to be stacked, oil to be drilled, gold to be mined, opportunities to be harvested. Data are humans to be seen, maybe loved, hopefully taken care of. And she was writing in the context of COVID-19 data, however I believe this is true of all medical data that we have in the world, however I believe this is true of all medical data and many, many other types of data as well. Thank you.
